block.p: FOR CHILDREN
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' presents a bee who rejects toiling in the hive and decides instead to fly off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Staged by the Culture Project. Maya's story is told through rod and shadow puppets. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, at Lafayette Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
FOR CHILDREN
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' presents a bee who rejects toiling in the hive and decides instead to fly off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Staged by the Culture Project. Maya's story is told through rod and shadow puppets. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, at Lafayette Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''THE BIG MOUTH MOUSE,'' a puppet show based on a traditional Japanese fable about a father who brags that no mere mouse is great enough to marry his beautiful daughter, who has fallen in love with a cheese-delivery boy. Tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. at New Perspectives Theater Company, 750 Eighth Avenue, at 46th Street, Clinton. Tickets: $6. Reservations: (212) 730-2030.

''CAREFULLY TAUGHT.'' What is school about? Teenagers of AMAS Musical Theater's musical theater program try to answer this question in poems, songs and dance. Today at 7:30 p.m.; tomorrow at 3 and 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. John Houseman Studio Theater, 450 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 239-4324.

''CHARLOTTE'S WEB,'' E. B. White's classic tale of Wilbur the pig and Charlotte the spider by Theaterworks/USA, at Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, off exit 9E of the Grand Central Parkway near Shea Stadium. Tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. Free trolley service between the Willets Point/Shea Stadium stop of the No. 7 train. Tickets: $8. Information: (718) 760-0064.

''KINGDOM OF THE SUN,'' directed by Zac Whinnem, is about knights and courtiers, Monty Python style. The play, by Josh Cagan, is also a feminist fairy tale in which the king's female page, Harold, saves him and longs to be a knight. Sunday at 2 p.m. Manhattan Theater Source, 177 Macdougal Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $7. Reservations: (212) 501-4751.

''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD/LA CAPERUCITA ROJA,'' a bilingual musical play (performed in Spanish and English simultaneously), written and directed by Manuel Antonio Moran, tells the familiar story but with a twist. Riding Hood does not believe the wolf is a wolf, which leads the wolf to have an identity crisis. Saturdays at 3:30 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. through June 25. Los Kabayitos Theater, second floor, 107 Suffolk Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $10; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 260-4080, extension 14.

''MULTICULTURAL STORY SALAD 2,'' a musical featuring children's stories, including ''Caps for Sale,'' ''Amelia Bedelia Goes Camping'' and ''Uncle Nacho's Hat.'' Tomorrow at 2 p.m. at Children's Theater Festival, Leon M. Goldstein Performing Arts Center, Kingsborough Community College, City University of New York, 2001 Oriental Boulevard, Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. Tickets: $8. Reservations: (718) 368-5596.

''SINGIN' IN THE RAIN, a production by Downtown Art based on the Hollywood musical, complete with gallons of real water, and presented by actors 12 to 19 years old. Through May 28. Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 p.m. (but no performance today); Sundays at 2 p.m. Downtown Art, 64 East Fourth Street, East Village. Tickets: $5; ages 18 and under, $4. Reservations: (212) 505-0835.

''SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN DWARFS,'' an adaptation by the Y.M.C.A.'s Kids Company, with youngsters trained in musical theater who perform for other children. In this musical, Snow White is a hip teenager and the Mirror is the Queen's psychologist. Tonight at 7 and tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the West Side Y.M.C.A. Little Theater, 5 West 63rd Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 875-4277.
Events

''ANGELS AND SOUTHERN FOLK TALES.'' Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, (212) 595-9533. In conjunction with the opening of ''The Art of William Edmondson,'' an exhibition of works by this Southern African-American artist whose limestone carvings include images of angelsand real and imaginary animals, there will be a program for children tomorrow at 4 p.m. with a storyteller, Deidre Caproni. Free.

BIG APPLE CIRCUS. The circus celebrates the clown in ''Bello and Friends,'' at Cunningham Park, Queens. The Big Top is on 196-22 Union Turnpike at Francis Lewis Boulevard in Fresh Meadows. Today at 11 a.m. and 6:30 p.m.; tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $12 to $32. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-4100.

BREAKFAST AND STORYTIME WITH THE CAT IN THE HAT. The Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Avenue, Crown Heights, is holding a breakfast and books event on Sunday at 10 a.m. and noon. Free with suggested $4 museum admission; space is limited so reservations are requested: (718) 735-4402.

''BUILD A GLIDER.'' Leonardo da Vinci's drawings will be the subject of a workshop tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The workshop is $2 plus museum admission: $4; free for children under 2 and members. Information: (718) 273-2060.

KIDS' COMPANY, a troupe of youngsters 11 to 18 years old selected in auditions all over the city in a program of Dancewave, will perform works by the choreographers Mark Morris and David Dorfman in their spring benefit on Sunday from 5 to 7 p.m. at Camp Friendship, 339 Eighth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Ticket prices start at $25. Information: (718) 622-1810.

EARTH CELEBRATIONS' RITES OF SPRING: PROCESSION TO SAVE OUR GARDENS is an all-day parade and pageant tomorrow to preserve community gardens in New York City. The eight-hour event begins at Forsythe Street, between Broome and Delancey Streets, at 10 a.m., with visits to more than 35 gardens in the East Village. The closing ceremony, at 6 p.m. on Eighth Street between Avenues C and D, will feature the release of 50 butterflies. Free. Information: (212) 777-7969.

''GLASS REFLECTIONS WORKSHOP.'' A design workshop in which children ages 6 to 12 will learn the art of glassmaking with Beth Lipman, an artist and teacher, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 3:30 p.m. at the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, 18 West 86th Street, Manhattan. Fee: $10, includes materials and refreshment. Advance registration required. Information: (212) 501-3011.

''THE MEDIEVAL SCRIBE: A FAMILY WORKSHOP.'' Karen Gorst is to lead a workshop for ages 4 and up on different types of book arts, from binding to painted letters, tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. Fee: $5. Reservations: (212) 932-7347.

''MEET THE MAESTRO,'' a Lolli-pops concert presented by the Little Orchestra Society is to feature the conductor Dino Anagnost teaching children ages 3 to 5 about the art of conducting, with help from the animal characters Bang the Lion, Bow the Panda and Toot the Bird. Tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. and noon; Sunday at 12:30 and 2 p.m. Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $32. Reservations: (212) 971-9500.

''REMEMBER PLAYING MARBLES?'' Smooth pieces of colored glass -- shiners, aggies and cat's eyes -- have been present in most world cultures, including African, Aztec, Egyptian and Venetian. In conjunction with the ''You Gotta Have Park'' events tomorrow and Sunday and every weekend through July 2, the Prospect Park Alliance and Urban Glass are presenting ''Marble Millennium: Historic and Contemporary Marble Exhibit,'' at the Grand Army Plaza Arch Gallery in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, exhibiting more than 100 historical and contemporary marbles. Marble enthusiasts will conduct workshops on traditional marble games under the arch on Saturdays and Sundays from noon to 4 p.m. Visitors are asked to donate $1 or more for park maintenance at the park's major entrances. The No. 2 and No. 3 trains and the B41 and B69 buses go to Grand Army Plaza. Information: (718) 965-8954.

REPTILES, REPTILES AND MORE REPTILES. The world of reptiles, from iguanas to boas and snakes and turtles, will be the subject of the science club program tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George. For youngsters 8 to 13. Reservations: (718) 727-1135, extension 15.

YOUNG PEOPLE'S TAP DANCE CONFERENCE. Young tappers from New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania will gather to perform, exchange ideas and present awards to the teachers and tappers Marion Coles and Eleanor Harris. Sunday at 2 p.m. at Brandeis High School, 145 West 84th Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $10; $5 for children under 12. The festivities culminate in Tap Extravaganza 2000, a tap-and-jazz concert Sunday, May 28, at 7 p.m. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan. Information: (718) 597-4613.
Zoos

''SHEAR MADNESS,'' Staten Island Zoo, 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton. Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. there will be haircuts for all. Peter Sepe is to be trimming the zoo's flock (followed by a demonstration by the Staten Island Handspinners and Weavers who turn wool into yarn) while professional hair stylists will be giving $10 trims to visitors. All proceeds go to benefit the zoo. Admission: $3; children 3 to 11, $2; under 3, free. Information: (718) 442-3101.
